text:
Anyone have thoughts on names for content hubs?

Planning out a website for a client and it will eventually have a content hub/library - currently it's more of a resource hub but as our design/dev team builds the site, my team will start creating content for it and it will grow over time. The goal is to be a place with a wealth of information for their audience, freely giving educational info and resources.

However, the client didn't like the name we suggested, "learning center" and suggested "resource hub," but to me resource hub implies specific resources and does not include educational articles and such. I can do some keyword research but I'm not sure the name is really that important for SEO. The client does association management so the content will all be around running associations (like American Diabetes Society and orgs like that). Could do a name more specific to the vertical (like Association 101) but I'm not sure that's necessary.

Anyone have best practices around naming this kind of thing?

elements.text:

I can do some keyword research but I'm not sure the name is really that important for SEO. The client does association management so the content will all be around running associations (like American Diabetes Society and orgs like that). Could do a name more specific to the vertical (like Association 101) but I'm not sure that's necessary.

Anyone have best practices around naming this kind of thing?

text: how clever are your names allowed to be?

elements.text: how clever are your names allowed to be?

text: Don't name it something confusing. I've had tons of clients call it "insights" and "learn" or whatever and if people are looking  for a blog on the site, they can't find it. Make it painfully obvious in the site nav.

elements.text: Don't name it something confusing. I've had tons of clients call it "insights" and "learn" or whatever and if people are looking  for a blog on the site, they can't find it. Make it painfully obvious in the site nav.

elements.text: why not just “resource library”

text: As clever as the client allows. They're pretty laid back but not, like, tech startup level laid back, they're overall professional. I can suggest whatever

elements.text: As clever as the client allows. They're pretty laid back but not, like, tech startup level laid back, they're overall professional. I can suggest whatever

text: Otherwise you're right, that name means nothing for SEO.

text: Best practice for me would just be making it obvious to users that are on a page that, when they see the link in the header or footer, that's the place to go to learn more.

text: This would be separate from the blog. Blog is named blog, this is more of a foundation for an evergreen spoke and hub (or collection of spokes and hubs) library.

text: Webflow calls theirs “Webflow University” and if you’re having all that educational content there, it seems a good fit. Or maybe “[industry] School”.

text: Yikes! I think that’s part of the discussion beforehand. I have small business clients where I do the keyword research and then give them ~3-7 topics/month based on all that data because if I give them the full spreadsheet it’s information overload for them. So, IMO it’s based on what you agreed to before you started. I’d def tell them that your expectations were NOT met with the scale of your business and their research.

Then additional keyword research would be done for specific pages or to recommend blog/resource type of content on a monthly basis outside of the core conversion keyword list.

text:
<@UJG9WTEKG>
At <http://Automate.io|Automate.io>, (a Notion.so  company),we do it in the below way.  I am sure this will vary from company to company.


*A) Old content Update.*

a) We create a sheet and add a priority matrix based for our already published blogs on factors like the average signups, traffic, etc.

Then we brainstorm internally to check what is needed to improve the ranking of those articles. It mostly comes down to - i) Content Update ii) CRO... where we check the placement of the CTA and sign up buttons, the design of those buttons etc.  iii) Backlinks needed to improve the ranking of any of those articles.
Once that is done, the SEO team, outreach team, etc is alloted the tasks.

*B) New content publishing.*

Using Ahrefs, GA, Keyword planner
and some internal data we create a sheet with the volume of the keywords, the difficulty of those keywords and the number of articles we need to publish around those keywords.

Once that is done we assign the tasks to the writing team/freelancers etc to work on the same.

*C) New Content Experiments.*

Every quarter we try new experiments. Recently we started using HARO and I dedicatedly work on that. We receive 8-10 backlinks from high DA websites every month. (PS: DM for more questions on HARO)

Other experiments include cross promotion activities with other SaaS brands for backlinks or any other ways.

D) Content Distribution/Community Building/Scheduling social posts.

This pretty much explains everything that we do. Happy to share more details and learn from others too.

Automate.io

A) Old content Update.

a) We create a sheet and add a priority matrix based for our already published blogs on factors like the average signups, traffic, etc.

Then we brainstorm internally to check what is needed to improve the ranking of those articles. It mostly comes down to - i) Content Update ii) CRO... where we check the placement of the CTA and sign up buttons, the design of those buttons etc.  iii) Backlinks needed to improve the ranking of any of those articles.
Once that is done, the SEO team, outreach team, etc is alloted the tasks.
B) New content publishing.

Using Ahrefs, GA, Keyword planner
and some internal data we create a sheet with the volume of the keywords, the difficulty of those keywords and the number of articles we need to publish around those keywords.

Once that is done we assign the tasks to the writing team/freelancers etc to work on the same.
C) New Content Experiments.

Every quarter we try new experiments. Recently we started using HARO and I dedicatedly work on that. We receive 8-10 backlinks from high DA websites every month. (PS: DM for more questions on HARO)

Other experiments include cross promotion activities with other SaaS brands for backlinks or any other ways.

D) Content Distribution/Community Building/Scheduling social posts.

This pretty much explains everything that we do. Happy to share more details and learn from others too.

text:
We do editorial planning every month, usually ~1 week in advance of the next month. We only plan content for the next month. (It's hard for us to plan with confidence beyond that. But if longer-term ideas come up, we also take note of those.)

We organize it like a "pitch off." Our agenda allocates 10 minutes of pitching for each of our main content types: (1) Search/SEO Blog Posts (based on keyword research), (2) Gated Content, (3) Customer Impact Stories, and (4) Catch-all for all other blog posts; thought leadership; viral/highly shareable ideas.

In each 10-minute segment, each team member has a chance to pitch their ideas.

After the planning meeting, each contributor is responsible for updating the calendar with the pieces they are most excited to pick up. Then I review the selections and approve (or redirect!).

text:
Five definitely isn't enough.

If this is for Path Factory; the keyword research should be pretty robust but run the full breadth of the ideal customers journey (from my perspective). What type of keywords are people typing into Google when they're learning about the problem you solve? What about when they've learned there are solutions out there for this problem? What about when they've learned a bit about these solutions? What about when they're comparing solutions? What about when they're using these solutions? All of these questions should lead to multiple variations of keywords.

text:
Agreed with <@U02546A8D2B>. We just like the TAM approach so we can understand as much as possible what’s out there. The idea being to get it all in one go so you can build models to figure out what aligns with business strategy (and some instances, even influence business strategy). 

Then distill that down to the most relevant topics with BOFU priority (where all those lucrative long-tails are).

But again, like <@UUXMCJQ15> said, this is where KWR turns into content strategy. Which, the only way I've found to effectively do them is having them hand in hand.

But damn, 5….that’s what, a keyword and some related searches/autosuggest? :upside_down_face: What did their SOW detail?

text: We do it much more sporadically but being a small content team of 2 we find the most value comes from involving other members of the company particularly those from product to get their input and ideas. We forget about SEO for the purposes of these idea generation meeting. The idea is just to get the ideas down and particularly focus on ones that can sell the business - product marketing stuff.
